# TESS Program G04206

Title: Mapping Star Spots Using TESS

PI: Daylan, Tansu - Massachusetts Institute Of Technology

Type: SMALL

Summary: Star spots are an interesting and ubiquitous phenomena that indicate the magnetic activity of stars, potentially interfere with exoplanet detection and characterization, and determine the habitability of planets hosted. We propose to analyze and model spot-induced rotational variability in light curves of bright stars selected based on their ground-based (ASAS-SN) variability in order to produce reliable spot maps with well-characterized uncertainties. These spot maps can be used to study habitability around low-mass stars and shed light onto the size and latitude distribution and dynamical lifetimes of their spots as well as the differential rotation of the stars. Complementary to stellar flare, studies of star spots yield independent insight into stellar magnetism.
